listCustomFeats.name: A Lie is Contagious
listCustomFeats.textDescription:
Saving Throw: Will
The seed of a single lie can grow into something much more dangerous. Choose a single statement you want a target to believe. The fact could be narrow, such as “an ogre is standing right behind me”; wide-reaching, such as “the city guard cannot be trusted”; or conceptual, such as “piety is the key the happiness.” The targets' experiences color how they react to this “truth” and how their behavior changes. If the statement changes what they perceive, they treat the change as a sudden revelation.
The captivated creature must attempt a Will save. If the captivated creature is already subject to a magical effect that forces them to believe a contradicting statement, you try to counteract it using a Performance or Deception check. If the counteract check fails, the target automatically succeeds their saving throw.
Critical Success: The target doesn't believe the statement, and is immune to this effect for 1 week.
Success: As for critical success.
Failure: The target believes the statement for a duration of 1 week.
Critical Failure: As for failure, and they will enthusiastically try to convince others that this statement is true; each person they speak to must make the same Will save. Targets affected in this way that are already subject to a magical effect that forces them to believe another contradicting statement succeed automatically.
As usual for an effect with the reveal trait, the effect ends on the captivated creature if you captivate another creature. However, other creatures that believe the statement remain under the effect even if another creature is captivated.

listCustomFeats.name: Acrobalance
listCustomFeats.textDescription: What might appear to be an incredible sense of balance is often just a clever application of physics. If you would fail or critically fail an acrobatics check to perform the Balance action whilst this effect is active, you succeed instead.

listCustomFeats.name: Acrobatic Flair
listCustomFeats.textDescription: You could be an acrobat with the right training, but a clever trick or two can be just as impressive. While this effect is active, once each round, after succeeding on an acrobatics check, you may strike as a free action.

listCustomFeats.name: Animated Blade
listCustomFeats.textDescription: Steel follows your whims just as easily as you'd whistle a tune. A weapon in your hand gains the effects of the Dancing rune, and is activated immediately. This weapon does not require you make the flat check each round for it to remain active. The weapon's Strikes have an attack modifier of your level plus 11, plus its item bonus to attack rolls.

listCustomFeats.name: Astounding Improvisation
listCustomFeats.textDescription:
Requirements: Keeping it Fresh
Sometimes it pays off to push your performance outside your script. Replace one of your trick or reveal feats with a different trick or reveal feat, using the same process as Keeping it Fresh.

listCustomFeats.name: Behind You All Along
listCustomFeats.textDescription: If you can get someone looking the wrong way, you can open a blind spot to move through quickly. When you take this action, you can move to any space that is adjacent to the creature captivated by you. You may use this action even if you are not adjacent to the creature. Like the Step action, this movement doesn't trigger reactions, such as Reactive Strike, that can be triggered by move actions or upon leaving or entering a square.

listCustomFeats.name: Behind Your Ear
listCustomFeats.textDescription: An object that can't be seen could be anywhere, so your pockets are powerful tools. While this effect is active, whenever you place an object of light bulk or less into your pocket, sleeve, or bag, you may choose to immediately teleport the object to the pocket of a chosen ally.

listCustomFeats.name: Betraying Glance
listCustomFeats.textDescription: A quick glance can alert someone to an unseen threat, but your eyes aren't to be trusted. You look past a creature you have captivated as though there were a threat behind them, causing them to move in the direction of real harm. Until the start of the creature's next turn, the first time an ally makes an attack roll against that creature, the ally rolls twice and uses the better result. The captivated creature does not recognize this as a hostile action.

listCustomFeats.name: But You're Me!
listCustomFeats.textDescription:
Saving Throw: Fortitude
With a trick mirror, you briefly convince someone that they have been transformed to look just like you. The captivated creature makes a Fortitude save.
Critical Success: The target is unaffected.
Success: The target becomes stunned 1, and takes on your physical appearance. Whilst the target is under this effect, attacks made against you must succeed a DC 10 flat check, otherwise hitting the target instead, if possible.
Failure: As for success, but the target becomes stunned 2.
Critical Failure: As for success, but the target is not stunned, and instead, the target becomes controlled by you. The target's statistics and abilities all change to match yours, with the exception of its hit points and hit point maximum. Any time the target takes damage, they make a new Fortitude save, ending the effect on a success or better. The effect of any abilities the target used while transformed end when this effect ends.

listCustomFeats.name: Chance Grab
listCustomFeats.textDescription:
Trigger: You or another creature falls from or past an edge or handhold.
When someone falls over an edge, there's a moment where they are out of sight which you have learned to exploit. The triggering creature, if willing, automatically grabs the edge, regardless of whether or not it has a hand free. They still take damage from the distance already fallen.

listCustomFeats.name: Collective Delusion
listCustomFeats.textDescription: It takes a special skill to keep the focus of an entire group locked on you. There is no longer a limit to the number of creatures you can have captivated at once.

listCustomFeats.name: Contortion
listCustomFeats.textDescription: By carefully working your muscles and ligaments you've achieved a degree of suppleness many would consider unnatural. You gain the Quick Squeeze feat, even if you do not meet the requirements. You may also treat lesser cover as though it is standard cover, and standard as though it is greater. At the GM's discretion, it may be possible to take cover behind objects that would normally be too narrow, such as a small tree or a vase.

listCustomFeats.name: Corner of Your Eye
listCustomFeats.textDescription: By distracting your opponent, you can stay just out of sight and dance around them freely. While this effect is active, your use of move actions doesn't trigger reactions, such as Reactive Strike, provided that your movement does not take you further than 10 feet from the creature.

listCustomFeats.name: Cut in Half
listCustomFeats.textDescription: Sawing a lady in half is a classic trick, but it can be pushed far beyond a single slice. Choose a creature that has the paralyzed or unconscious conditions and is of your level or lower. These restrictions can be ignored if the creature is willing. You separate the creature into as many as 8 pieces, but no damage is dealt to it. The creature gains the unconscious condition if it did not already have it, and will remain unconscious until another creature uses the interact action to put all the pieces back together. The pieces are invulnerable, and the target is in a state of suspended animation whilst under this effect. The pieces naturally pull towards each other, and will reassemble themselves after a period of 1 month, regardless of the distance between them.

listCustomFeats.name: Distraction Draw
listCustomFeats.textDescription:
Requirements: You are wielding a melee weapon.
By making an exaggerated feint with your weapon, you can draw a hidden weapon to make an unexpected attack. Feint against the captivated creature, but a critical failure is treated as a failure. Drop the melee weapon you are wielding. Draw a new one-handed weapon. Make a strike with the new weapon against the captivated creature.

listCustomFeats.name: Double Whammy
listCustomFeats.textDescription:
Trigger: You use an action with the Trick trait.
Two tricks are always better than one, and you've perfected the art of sneaking in a second surprise just when your mark thought the show was over. As part of your daily preparations, choose one of your actions with the trick trait that takes 1 action to perform. You can perform both the triggering action and the prepared action at the same time, and both effects apply. Should it matter in which order the actions are performed, the prepared action was performed last. You cannot use this reaction again until you have made your next daily preparations.

listCustomFeats.name: Escapology
listCustomFeats.textDescription: Escaping from restraints is a cornerstone of the magician creed, which you have now added to your repertoire. While this effect is active, whenever you attempt to Escape an effect that has you immobilized, grabbed, or restrained, using acrobatics or athletics, and you fail or critically fail, you succeed instead.

listCustomFeats.name: Fire Breathing
listCustomFeats.textDescription:
It might cost you your eyebrows, but fire breathing is always a crowd-pleaser. While this effect is active, you may cast breathe fire at 1st rank without expending a spell slot and using your magician class DC for the spell's DC.
Level (+2) Spell rank increases by 1.

listCustomFeats.name: Firewalking
listCustomFeats.textDescription: With care, it is possible to walk over burning embers without injury, and you are able to stretch that fact to its limits. While this effect is active, you gain resistance to fire damage equal to your level, and immunity to fire damage taken from standing on solid hot surfaces.

listCustomFeats.name: Flying Blade
listCustomFeats.textDescription: With the right application of momentum and spin, any weapon can be made to glide through the air. You make a ranged strike with a weapon you are holding, which does not have the thrown trait and is not etched with a Returning rune. For the purpose of this attack, the weapon has a range increment of 20 feet.

listCustomFeats.name: Hand Off
listCustomFeats.textDescription: With clever contortion, you can convince your mark that your hand is separated from your wrist, allowing it to get up to mischief in your stead. You separate your hand from your body, which becomes a tiny minion as though you had the Pet feat, but this pet shares your Hit Points. The hand has the climber and manual dexterity pet abilities. You can communicate with the hand telepathically and effortlessly, as though it were still attached to your arm. You do not need to take the Command an Animal action; the hand gains 2 actions on your turn automatically. When this effect ends, the hand is immediately forcefully dragged back to its normal position at the end of your arm, ignoring gravity. If the hand is unable to return to your arm when this effect ends, you remain without a hand, and are no longer able to communicate with the hand; in this case, the hand will continue to use its actions each turn to free itself as best as it is able.

listCustomFeats.name: How Many Shots?
listCustomFeats.textDescription: It's hard to keep track of how many shots a weapon has fired, so who really cares if you're off by one or two? Whenever you make a ranged strike that consumes ammunition, make a DC 11 flat check. If you succeed, no ammunition is consumed by the weapon for that strike.

listCustomFeats.name: Hypnosis
listCustomFeats.textDescription:
Saving Throw: Fortitude
Careful control of the tone of your voice sends your audience into an inescapable slumber. All creatures within a 10-foot emanation centered on your captivated creature must make a fortitude save against your magician class DC. Any creature that fails or critically fails gains the unconscious condition and may not attempt perception checks to wake up.

listCustomFeats.name: Immovable
listCustomFeats.textDescription: When an object is dropped, there's often a moment of uncertainty where it appears as though it might not fall at all. Choose an object the creature captivated by you can see that fits within a 10 foot cube. That object becomes anchored in place, defying gravity if need be. While anchored, the object can be moved only if 8,000 pounds of pressure are applied to it or if a creature uses Athletics to Force Open the object against your class DC plus 5. As part of taking this action, you may move the object around anywhere within your reach before the anchoring effect takes hold, allowing you to hold the object up before it is anchored. If the object is successfully moved, it remains anchored in its new position. You may deactivate the anchoring effect as a free action on your turn.

listCustomFeats.name: Impossible Showmanship
listCustomFeats.textDescription: Your performances end with legendary displays. You immediately make two actions with the reveal trait which each cost 1 action.

listCustomFeats.name: Infeasible Permeation
listCustomFeats.textDescription: Utilizing tiny cracks and holes you slowly work yourself through a surface, appearing to simply disappear through it. You attempt to pass through either a wall or floor to the other side. Your attempt fails if the wall or floor is made of something other than wood, plaster, or stone; is thicker than 10 feet; or contains even a thin layer of metal. If you have a climb speed, you can use this ability to attempt to move through a ceiling.

listCustomFeats.name: Inflatable Yous
listCustomFeats.textDescription:
Range: 40 feet Area: 20-foot burst
Copies of you spill out from a point, seemingly countless. The chosen area is instantly filled with copies of an ally of your choice (you may choose yourself). The copies, though visually identical to the ally, are inflatable and constructed from a rubber-like material. If the copies move outside the area or are damaged, they immediately burst in a harmless explosion of confetti, but new copies immediately appear to fill the emptied space. Hostile creatures in the area are off-guard towards you and the ally, and the area counts as difficult terrain for them. The clones attack weakly, dealing 8d4 nonlethal bludgeoning damage to an enemy that enters or starts its turn inside the area. While the chosen ally is inside the area, they gain the hidden condition, and creatures using the Seek action to find the ally must roll a Perception check against your class DC instead of the ally's Stealth DC, if it is higher.
Level (+2) The damage increases by 1d4.

listCustomFeats.name: Is This Your Card?
listCustomFeats.textDescription:
Saving Throw: Will
Even simple magic can create a moment of confusion. The captivated creature makes a will save against your class DC.
Critical Success: The creature is unaffected.
Success: The creature is stupefied 1 for 1 round.
Failure: The creature is stupefied 2 for 1 round.
Critical Failure: The creature is clumsy 1 and stupefied 2 for 1 round.

listCustomFeats.name: Lightning Strikes Twice
listCustomFeats.textDescription:
Range: 50 feet, Area: 10-foot burst
Saving Throw: Basic Reflex
It takes some incredible luck for your enemy to get struck by lightning, but luck always seems to be in your favor. A bolt of lightning strikes the next two targets to enter the area, who each make a basic reflex save against your class DC, dealing 3d10 electricity damage. If multiple targets enter the area simultaneously, you choose the order they entered for the purpose of this effect.
Level (+3) The damage of each bolt increases by 1d10.

listCustomFeats.name: Look Out!
listCustomFeats.textDescription:
When someone points and shouts, you can't help but look up. A large object of the GM's choosing falls from above the captivated creature, however infeasible. All creatures within a 5-foot emanation centered on the creature must make a reflex save against your class DC. Creatures that are not captivated by you have a +2 circumstance bonus to the save.
Critical Success: The creature is unaffected.
Success: The creature takes bludgeoning damage equal to your level.
Failure: The creature takes bludgeoning damage equal to twice your level.
Critical Failure: The creature takes bludgeoning damage equal to five times your level.

listCustomFeats.name: Master of Blades
listCustomFeats.textDescription: With a few flashy tricks, it is easy to look convincingly skilled with a weapon. While this effect is active, you gain proficiency with advanced weapons of a single group of your choice, as though they were simple weapons of that group.

listCustomFeats.name: Missed All My Organs!
listCustomFeats.textDescription:
Trigger: You use your That Was A Close One! reaction.
Sometimes, a single injury isn't convincing enough, so a master magician will up the stakes. You remain immune to physical damage caused by the attack that triggered your That was a Close One! reaction until you captivate another creature. For example, if a Minotaur's greataxe triggered your reaction, your would be immune to physical damage caused by any further greataxe attacks the Minotaur makes, but not immune to its horn attacks.

listCustomFeats.name: More than a Stick
listCustomFeats.textDescription: Some magicians carry wands, but they aren't just for show. You cast a spell from a wand you are carrying, using your magician class DC for the wand's DC, rather than a particular spell DC. If a spell is on the spell list for multiple traditions, you choose which tradition to use.

listCustomFeats.name: Occular Confinement
listCustomFeats.textDescription:
Requirements: You are within 5 feet of a creature captivated by you, and both you and that creature can see your target.
Saving Throw: Will
They say that light can be captured within some gemstones forever, but you are able to capture much more than that. Choose a target of size large or smaller. You hold up a small refractive object such as a gemstone or a marble, such that it entirely covers the target from the perspective of the creature captivated by you. You attempt to trap the target within the object. The target makes a will save against your Magician class DC. A trapped target may take actions as normal, but must break the object in order to be released, which it can do by making strikes against it.
Critical Success: The target is unaffected.
Success: The target is trapped for 1 round.
Failure: The target is trapped for 3 rounds, and stunned 1.
Critical Failure: The target is trapped for 1 minute, and stunned 3.

listCustomFeats.name: Out of the Hat
listCustomFeats.textDescription:
Range: 10 feet
Old classics are always well-received, and there is nothing more iconic than pulling a rabbit from a hat, though other animals might be equally impressive. You summon a creature that has the animal trait, as though casting summon animal of rank equal to half your level rounded up, to fight for you.

listCustomFeats.name: Out with a Bang
listCustomFeats.textDescription: An explosion makes any performance thrilling, but also leaves an opening for you to exploit. You immediately activate a consumable item with the bomb trait with the captivated creature as the target. You may then stride, and then hide, without triggering reactions that can be triggered by move actions or upon leaving or entering a square.

listCustomFeats.name: Overselling Danger
listCustomFeats.textDescription: A good performer raises the tension by convincing their mark that the stakes are greater than they seem. While this effect is active, any weapon you make a strike with gains the Deadly (d10) trait if it did not have the deadly or fatal trait already.

listCustomFeats.name: Parlor Tricks
listCustomFeats.textDescription: Not every performance needs an audience. You spend 10 minutes performing without needing to captivate a creature, before taking an action with the reveal trait costing 1 to 3 actions that you have access to.

listCustomFeats.name: Perfect Arc
listCustomFeats.textDescription: You have practiced with the precise geometry and aerodynamics of weapons so well that any throw can be made to ricochet back to your hand. While this effect is active, when you make a thrown strike with any weapon, that weapon is considered to also have the recovery trait, and therefore returns to your hand after an unsuccessful strike (falling to the ground in your space if your hands are full when the weapon returns).

listCustomFeats.name: Perspective Shift
listCustomFeats.textDescription:
Perspective is a funny thing, and in the right circumstances it can be hard to tell exactly what size something really is. You may immediately either grow to be Large in size, or shrink to become Tiny in size. Your equipment changes size with you but returns to natural size if removed.
If you grow to become Large in size, and are immediately pushed away from the captivated creature by 10 feet. Your reach increases by 5 feet (10 feet if you were Tiny) and you gain a +2 status bonus to melee damage. You gain resistance to bludgeoning damage equal to your level.
If you shrink to become Tiny in size, and are immediately teleported to the captivated creature such that you occupy their space. You gain a +2 circumstance bonus to AC. Your reach decreases to 0 feet.

listCustomFeats.name: Read Thoughts
listCustomFeats.textDescription: You know how to make suitably generic guesses such that someone believes you are reading their mind. While this effect is active, you can perceive the vague surface thoughts of your captivated creature.

listCustomFeats.name: Rug Pull
listCustomFeats.textDescription:
Range: 20 feet, Area: 20-foot burst
Saving Throw: Will
As though pulling a tablecloth out from under dinner plates, you can pull the ground out from under your enemies, even if only a little. Choose a direction to push hostile creatures in the area 15 feet in. Hostile creatures in the area must make a Will Save.
Critical Success: The creature is unaffected.
Success: The creature is pushed 15 feet in the chosen direction.
Failure: As success, but the creature is also knocked prone.
Critical Failure: As failure, but the creature is also immobilized for 1 round.

listCustomFeats.name: Runic Blur
listCustomFeats.textDescription:
Trigger: You draw a weapon, and are no longer wielding a weapon you held previously.
A master of myriad blades would need a hefty supply of runic weapons to keep pace, or a way to duplicate runic magic with a quick sleight of hand. Copy any number of the runes from the weapon you are no longer wielding to your new weapon. Runes which the new weapon does not meet the requirements for have no effect. The runes copied no longer have any effect on the old weapon. If a rune had a limited number of uses, the depleted uses are carried over to the new weapon. At the end of your next turn, the runes return to their original weapon. You may use this ability to copy from weapons with runes duplicated in this way.

listCustomFeats.name: Shallow Breathing
listCustomFeats.textDescription: Escapology often leaves you trapped in enclosed spaces, where it is important to maintain good control over your breathing. You gain the benefits of the Breath Control feat, except that you gain a +3 circumstance bonus to saving throws against inhaled threats.

listCustomFeats.name: Shared Experience
listCustomFeats.textDescription: A great performance is all the sweeter when it's shared, and you are more than happy to oblige. You may use your Choose a Mark action on second creature, without ending the captivation on the first. You may not have more than two creatures captivated at a time. If you use an action with the reveal trait, you choose which captivation ends. Whenever an effect refers to 'the captivated creature' you must decide which one of your captivated creatures that effect applies to.

listCustomFeats.name: Slow Fall
listCustomFeats.textDescription: You are able to use the wind under your cloak to slow your descent on an otherwise dangerous fall. You can fall no faster than 60 feet per round, and take no damage from falls. If this effect ends while you are still falling, fall damage is calculated as though you fell from the height you were at when the effect ended.

listCustomFeats.name: Speechless
listCustomFeats.textDescription: Some performances are so good that they leave the audience in silent awe. Creatures that are captivated by you are unable to speak, use auditory actions, or cast spells, with the exception of subtle spells.

listCustomFeats.name: Static Shock
listCustomFeats.textDescription:
Static electricity may seem perplexing to those unfamiliar, and you can leverage this to give yourself an inexplicable edge in battle. When you make a successful melee strike against a creature, that creature becomes charged. A charged creature suffers 2d8 electricity damage when it next makes a melee strike or uses a manipulate action. After suffering this damage the creature ceases to be charged.
Level (+3) The damage increases by 1d8.

listCustomFeats.name: That was a Close One!
listCustomFeats.textDescription:
Trigger: You are hit by an attack that would deal physical damage.
The only thing that shocks more than an unexpected gory accident is a magician walking away from the accident unscathed. You become immune to physical damage caused by the triggering attack, for that attack only.

listCustomFeats.name: Through Fire and Flame
listCustomFeats.textDescription: To rise from ashes unharmed is as useful a skill as it is thematic. While this effect is active, you are immune to fire damage.

listCustomFeats.name: Time Flies
listCustomFeats.textDescription:
Area: 100-foot emanation
When watching a truly incredible performance, it's easy to lose track of time. When you take this action, choose either a minute, an hour, or a day. Each round of combat for creatures within the area now takes this length of time, though they do not perceive the flow of time to have changed. Creatures that enter the area immediately begin to experience this effect, and any effects upon them with limited duration immediately end. Creatures may leave the area freely, at which point they cease to be under this effect. A creature that is under the effect and can see past the edge of the area will realize that it is under the effect of time manipulation. Due to turbulence in time, creatures outside the area are unable to affect those within it, such that attacks made across the threshold are completely ineffective, and spells cast into the area fizzle out before they take any effect.

listCustomFeats.name: Topsy-Turvy
listCustomFeats.textDescription:
Area: 20-foot emanation
Saving Throw: Fortitude
In the heat of battle, it can be hard to keep track of which way is up. Choose any number of creatures and objects in the area, which must each make a fortitude save against your class DC (objects are considered to have critically failed). Any target that is fixed in place is unaffected.
Critical Success: The target is unaffected.
Success: The target is knocked prone.
Failure: Gravity is inverted for the target, and will fall upwards for 20 feet.
Critical Failure: As for failure, but the target falls for 40 feet.
A creature might be able to Grab an Edge to arrest its fall if it falls past an appropriate surface. If a creature falls against a solid object (such as a ceiling), it takes the appropriate amount of falling damage and lands on the surface, and the effect ends on that creature at the end of its next turn. Once an object or creature reaches the top of the area, it floats, and the effect ends on that creature at the end of its next turn. Most creatures are unable to move whilst under this effect, but creatures that can levitate or fly can use those abilities to mitigate this effect. The effect ends on any creature that leaves the area.

listCustomFeats.name: Universal Specialization
listCustomFeats.textDescription: By concentrating, you can replicate specialist techniques you've seen elsewhere, provided you spend time visualizing those techniques in advance. When you succeed at an attack roll with a weapon you are at least trained in, you may apply the critical specialization effect for that weapon. Once you have done this, you may not do so again with a weapon of the same weapon group until you next perform your daily preparations. You may still apply the critical specialization effects as permitted by other class features.

listCustomFeats.name: Up Your Sleeve
listCustomFeats.textDescription: With how many things you can hide up your sleeve, you might as well have your entire bag in there. While this effect is active, you may remove items from your bag as a free action.

listCustomFeats.name: Was That Aimed at Me?
listCustomFeats.textDescription: It's always dangerous to fire an arrow into a crowded room; there's no telling who might get hit. While this effect is active, enemies not captivated by you have a -4 circumstance penalty to ranged attacks made against you. If such an attack misses you, it is instead made against the creature captivated by you, using the same dice roll.

listCustomFeats.name: Waterwalking
listCustomFeats.textDescription: With a little setup, it is easy to make it appear as if you are walking on water. You can walk on the surface of water and other liquids without falling through, and you may consider the surface of the water to be solid for the purposes of standing on it. You can go underwater if you wish, but in that case you must Swim normally. This action doesn't grant the ability to breathe underwater.

listCustomFeats.name: Weightless Blade
listCustomFeats.textDescription: In a flourish of steel you reveal that your weapon is incredibly light, almost weightless, allowing you to wield it with stunning dexterity. The weapons which you have equipped gain the agile trait. The effect ends if you unequip a weapon.

listCustomFeats.name: Wrong Turn
listCustomFeats.textDescription:
Range: 100 feet
Navigating twisting corridors can be disorientating, and a powerful magician can use this to fold space onto itself. Choose two areas within range, which each fit within 30 foot bursts, which do not overlap and have no line of sight between them, of identical shapes and dimensions. The areas shimmer with unnatural light. Every time a creature enters or leaves either area, you may choose to teleport them such that they enter or leave the other area. The areas may be rotated relative to each other, though you must make this explicit when using this action. Projectiles pass through the areas normally. A creature which is aware of and understands the effect (which will usually require that they have entered one of the areas at least once) may make an occultism check against your class DC, becoming immune to the effect on a success.

listCustomFeats.name: You Can’t?
listCustomFeats.textDescription:
Saving Throw: Will
With a little trickery, you can fool your audience into thinking a physical task should be simple, leaving them doubting their own abilities. Choose either athletics or acrobatics. The captivated creature makes a will save against your class DC.
Critical Success: The creature is unaffected.
Success: The creature gains a -1 status penalty to the chosen skill.
Failure: The creature gains a -2 status penalty to the chosen skill.
Critical Failure: The creature gains a -3 status penalty to the chosen skill.

listCustomClasses.name: Magician

listCustomSpecials.name: Choose a Mark
listCustomSpecials.description:
You choose a mark for your performance and begin leading them along towards your trick, setting up the circumstances for the grand reveal. Make a performance or deception check against the perception DC of a non-allied creature you can see, and who can perceive you. Until the end of your next turn, the target is captivated by you, with additional effects on a success. The creature does not recognize this as a hostile action. You can only have one creature captivated by you at any time.
The captivated creature becomes immune to your Choose a Mark ability for 1 minute.
Dealing damage to the captivated creature does not affect their captivation.
If you become unconscious, the creature ceases to be captivated by you.
Critical Success: As success, but the creature also gains the fascinated conditions towards you while captivated. The fascinated condition from this source does not end in response to hostile actions taken against the creature or their allies.
Success: The captivated creature gains the off-guard condition towards you while captivated.

listCustomSpecials.name: Broad Repetoire
listCustomSpecials.description:
You gain 2 magician feats. Should you retrain these feats, you may select a new feat of any level up to a quarter of your character level rounded up.
(Utilize the 'Custom Feat Choice' menu option to add these additional feats)

listCustomSpecials.name: Extended Run
listCustomSpecials.description:
Trigger: You begin your turn with a creature already captivated by you that you can still see.
It's not yet time for the big reveal, and the show must go on. Make a performance or deception check against the captivated creature's perception DC. If the result is a failure or better, the creature remains captivated by you until the end of your next turn.

listCustomSpecials.name: Blades Out
listCustomSpecials.description:
Trigger: You use your Choose a Mark ability.
All the greatest performances involve dangerous props, and your preferred danger is that of a sharp blade or weighty maul. You may draw a weapon, provided you have sufficient hands free to hold it.
You also gain an additional magician feat, following the same rules as for Broad Repertoire.
(Utilize the 'Custom Feat Choice' menu option to add these additional feats)

listCustomSpecials.name: Confident Stance
listCustomSpecials.description: Posture adds a lot to a performance. Your proficiency with fortitude saves raises to expert.

listCustomSpecials.name: Initial Proficencies (Additional)
listCustomSpecials.description: You are trained in either Performance or Deception

listCustomSpecials.name: Performance
listCustomSpecials.description: Trained in Performance

listCustomSpecials.name: Deception
listCustomSpecials.description: Trained in Deception

listCustomSpecials.name: Encore
listCustomSpecials.description:
Trigger: You use an ability with the reveal trait.
Your performance is so compelling that you can keep your mark strung along for multiple tricks. When you use the triggering ability, make performance or deception check against the perception DC of the captivated creature, with an untyped penalty equal to 5 multiplied by the number of times that creature has been captivated by you. If you succeed, that creature ceases to be immune to Choose a Mark.

listCustomSpecials.name: Magician Weapon Expertise
listCustomSpecials.description: Your talent for showmanship alone isn’t enough to win battles. Your proficiency rank for martial weapons, simple weapons, and unarmed attacks increases to expert.

listCustomSpecials.name: Well-Focused
listCustomSpecials.description: It takes significant focus to keep performing in the face of danger. Your proficiency rank for will saves increases to master. When you roll a success on a will save, you get a critical success instead.

listCustomSpecials.name: Weapon Specialization
listCustomSpecials.description: You’ve learned how to inflict greater injuries with the weapons you know best. You deal 2 additional damage with weapons and unarmed attacks in which you’re an expert. This damage increases to 3 if you’re a master, and 4 if you’re legendary.

listCustomSpecials.name: Magician Weapon Mastery
listCustomSpecials.description: Your show-stopping performances are paired with heart-stopping skill with a blade. Your proficiency rank for martial weapons, simple weapons, and unarmed attacks increases to master.

listCustomSpecials.name: Perception Expertise
listCustomSpecials.description: You remain alert to threats around you. Your proficiency rank for Perception increases to expert.

listCustomSpecials.name: Uncanny Reflexes
listCustomSpecials.description: Always aware of the narratives developing around you, your reflexes seem supernatural to others. Your proficiency rank for Reflex saves increases to master. When you roll a success on a Reflex save, you get a critical success instead.

listCustomSpecials.name: Keeping it Fresh
listCustomSpecials.description: You review and shake up your talents to make sure you're always ready to amaze. When you make your daily preparations, you can replace one of your trick or reveal feats with a different trick or reveal feat. This follows the same rules as retraining.

listCustomSpecials.name: Light Armor Expertise
listCustomSpecials.description: You've learned how to dodge while wearing light or no armor. Your proficiency ranks for light armor and unarmored defense increase to expert.

listCustomSpecials.name: Greater Weapon Specialization
listCustomSpecials.description: Your damage from weapon specialization increases to 4 with weapons and unarmed attacks in which you’re an expert, 6 if you’re a master, and 8 if you’re legendary.

listCustomSpecials.name: Greater Focus
listCustomSpecials.description: Nothing will distract you from delivering the perfect show. Your proficiency rank for will saves increases to legendary. When you roll a critical failure on a will save, you get a failure instead. When you fail a will save against an effect that deals damage, you halve the damage you take.

listCustomSpecials.name: Light Armor Mastery
listCustomSpecials.description: You've learned how to dodge while wearing light or no armor. Your proficiency ranks for light armor and unarmored defense increase to expert.

listCustomClasses.description:
Your talents are much more than merely flashy tricks. Whilst you are undoubtedly a sensational performer, you do much more than simply entertain. Whilst the idea of a suited man pulling bunnies from top hats is what has captured the hearts of many, magicians are able to pull far greater feats from the great tapestry by exploiting the disbelief their trickery evokes in others. Once someone believes that something unusual is about to occur, even if only for a moment, the will of a magician can effortlessly bring that thing into existence; the limits of the almost impossible are where magicians find their greatest strength. One could watch a padlock lie on a table for a hundred years and it would never spontaneously unlock, but that’s not to say that it’s impossible.
The audience to their performances need not be friendly, and it is actually fairly unusual for true magicians to perform for money or fame, instead using their performances to gain an advantage over their enemies as they clash blades. Enemies catch on to tricks quickly, severely limiting a magician’s capabilities after the first few unexpected twists. As such, a magician carefully manages the attention of their enemies, else risking being caught out without access to their reality-bending talents when they really need them.
Special Thanks to Taylor Lindise Balance Consulting!
